alt_statements.statement: As a Dominican mother raising young kids in this country, I want police who protect us, not who look at our skin or our neighborhood and assume we’re trouble. We need stronger rules, body cameras, real consequences when officers abuse their power, and better training so they know how to de-escalate instead of jumping straight to force. At the same time, I don’t want the streets left to gangs or chaos—I want officers who actually know our community, talk to us with respect, and work with us so everyone can feel safe.

As a Catholic, a mom, and someone who believes deeply in fairness, I think policing has to prioritize de-escalation, strict accountability, and unbiased treatment of everyone, especially communities that have historically been over-policed. We can’t truly have public safety if people are afraid of the very officers meant to protect them, so strategies like better training in mental health and implicit bias, body cameras, transparent investigations, and strong community oversight are essential. At the same time, I want officers to have the support and resources they need to safely respond to real threats, but within clear limits that respect human dignity and civil rights.

As someone who believes strongly in law and order and has spent a career assessing risk and reward, I think it’s possible—and necessary—to support both our police and sensible reforms. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, mental health, and unbiased decision-making, along with body cameras and clear, consistently enforced standards for use of force. At the same time, we need to back officers who follow the rules, ensure they have the resources to deal with rising crime, and avoid policies that demoralize them or make them hesitant to act when public safety is on the line.

I believe our police officers have a tough, essential job, and most are trying to do what’s right, but we can’t ignore real concerns about bias and excessive force. We should invest in better training that emphasizes de-escalation, consistent standards across departments, and body cameras to protect both citizens and officers. At the same time, we need to support law enforcement with the resources and respect they need to keep communities safe, not weaken them. Accountability and public safety should go hand in hand, not be pitted against each other.

As a conservative, family-oriented mom and school librarian, I believe we need policing that is both firm and fair—officers must be supported to do their jobs effectively while being held to high professional standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, improve screening and accountability for misconduct, and encourage stronger, respectful relationships between officers and the communities they serve. This way, we can address legitimate concerns about excessive force without undermining law and order, which is essential for safe schools and neighborhoods.

As a liberal, college-educated mom and educator, I believe policing strategies need to center on de-escalation, strong accountability measures, and rigorous bias training, backed by transparent data on stops and use of force. We can maintain public safety far more effectively by investing in mental health services, community-based violence prevention, and alternative crisis response teams, so that armed officers aren’t the default for every problem.

As someone who supervises people every day, I know that clear standards, training, and accountability are what keep both workers and the public safe, and I believe policing should be no different. We need strong, enforceable rules around de-escalation, bias training that’s grounded in real community input (especially from communities of color and immigrants), and independent oversight when force is used. At the same time, investing in mental health services, housing, and youth programs will reduce the situations that turn into police encounters in the first place, making our neighborhoods safer for everyone, including officers.

As someone who believes in law and order but also fairness, I think policing should focus on rigorous training, clear rules of engagement, and strict accountability so that officers use force only when truly necessary. We should support our police with better screening, ongoing bias and de-escalation training, body cameras, and strong leadership, while also backing them to act decisively to protect the public. I don’t think the answer is to “defund” the police, but to reform and professionalize the force so that communities—especially families like mine—can trust that the law is applied consistently and respectfully.

As someone who cares deeply about justice and community, I believe policing strategies must focus on strong de-escalation training, strict accountability for misconduct, and meaningful transparency, including body cameras and public reporting of use-of-force data broken down by race. We can maintain public safety while reducing bias by investing heavily in mental health responders, community-based violence prevention, and better screening and ongoing evaluation of officers, so that force is a last resort, not a default.

As someone who respects law enforcement and believes in law and order, I think we need to support our police with better training, clear rules, and the right equipment so they can do their jobs safely and fairly. At the same time, I’m not blind to the fact that bias and excessive force can happen, and when it does, it should be taken seriously with real accountability, not swept under the rug. I’d like to see more community policing, where officers actually know the neighborhoods and the people they serve, so there’s more trust on both sides. We can back the blue and demand high standards at the same time—that’s how you keep both public safety and public trust.

As someone who has lived a long life and seen many changes, I believe we need strong, well-supported police to keep communities safe, but they must be held to clear standards that apply fairly to everyone. Proper training in de-escalation, consistent use-of-force rules, and strong leadership that does not tolerate bias are all essential, but so is backing good officers when they do their jobs correctly.

As a mom and someone who wants my kids to grow up safe and respectful of authority, I think we need to back our police while also insisting on commonsense reforms. I support strong training in de-escalation, body cameras, and clear accountability for officers who abuse their power, but I don’t want policies that make cops afraid to do their jobs or keep criminals off the streets. We can reduce bias and excessive force through better hiring, training, and leadership without demonizing all law enforcement or sacrificing public safety.

As someone who makes a living connecting with people through music, I believe policing should be guided by de-escalation, strong community relationships, and strict accountability for excessive force or discriminatory practices. Officers need thorough, ongoing training in implicit bias and mental health response, along with clear use-of-force standards, body cameras, and independent review when things go wrong. At the same time, we should invest in community services and non-police crisis responders so officers aren’t asked to handle every social problem with a badge and a gun. That balance—firm oversight, smarter training, and shared responsibility for public safety—can help protect both civil rights and community security.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a hard job, and we need to support them while also holding them to high, consistent standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and recognizing bias, make body cameras standard, and ensure clear, fair consequences when force is misused. At the same time, departments need enough staffing, resources, and community backing so officers can respond quickly and confidently to real threats. That balance—strong accountability and strong support—is how we keep both our families and our freedoms safe.

I think policing needs way more accountability and de-escalation training so officers don’t jump straight to force, especially with people of color who keep getting treated unfairly. Body cameras, transparent investigations, and community review boards should be standard so we actually know what’s happening and can build trust. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be safe, so I’d rather see police working *with* communities—funding mental health services, youth programs, and conflict mediation—than just rolling in like an occupying force. That feels more in line with my values and my Buddhist beliefs about reducing harm.

As someone who’s Black and grew up around people who’ve had bad experiences with cops, I think police need better training on de-escalation and bias so they don’t jump to force, especially in our communities. But I also believe in law and order, so we shouldn’t weaken the police; we should hold officers accountable when they mess up while still giving the good ones the support, pay, and tools they need to keep us safe.

As someone who grew up under a regime in Cuba where the police were instruments of fear, I value strong but accountable law enforcement in this country. We should support our officers with better training in de-escalation and clear, consistent rules on use of force, while disciplining those who abuse their power based on bias. Body cameras, careful supervision, and community respect for the law can work together so that both the public and the police are protected. Public safety must never be sacrificed, but neither should fairness and equal treatment under the law.

As a cop, a dad, and someone who cares about civil rights, I think we need policing that’s both effective and fair, which means confronting bias and tightening up use-of-force standards without abandoning our duty to protect people. That starts with better training in de-escalation and implicit bias, body cameras and transparent reporting on stops and force, and real accountability when officers cross the line. At the same time, we need enough staffing, equipment, and community trust so officers can respond quickly to violent crime and emergencies. If we work with the community instead of policing as if we’re at odds with them, we can reduce unnecessary force and still keep our cities safe.

As a cop and a conservative, I believe we can address bias and use-of-force concerns without tying officers’ hands or compromising public safety. We need solid training based on real-world scenarios, clear use-of-force policies that are actually enforced, and body cameras that protect both the public and the officers. I support transparency and holding bad actors accountable, but I also expect the public and elected officials to respect the dangers of this job and not rush to judgment before the facts are in. The goal should be fair, consistent policing that treats everyone with dignity while still allowing us to do what’s necessary to protect our communities and get home safe to our families.

As an 87-year-old retired teacher, I’ve seen how unequal treatment from authorities can damage trust for generations, especially in communities of color and Native communities like those in my own family’s history. We need stronger, mandatory de-escalation and bias training, strict accountability when officers misuse force, and independent oversight so investigations aren’t just the police policing themselves. At the same time, we keep our communities safer by investing in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based responses, so officers aren’t asked to handle every social problem with a badge and a gun. True public safety means everyone can feel protected—not targeted—when they see those blue lights.

As a Cambodian-American Catholic and a conservative, I believe we need both strong, well-supported police and firm safeguards against abuse. Officers should receive rigorous, ongoing training in de-escalation, cultural awareness, and bias, along with clear, enforced standards for use of force and transparent accountability when those standards are violated. At the same time, we must ensure they have the resources, staffing, and community trust necessary to keep our neighborhoods safe, because families like mine depend on stability and order. Body cameras, community outreach, and consistent consequences for misconduct can help rebuild trust without undermining the essential authority of law enforcement.

As someone who’s seen a lot in my 92 years, I believe we need law and order, but we also need cops who treat everyone fairly and answer for their mistakes. Training should focus on de-escalation, knowing the community, and recognizing bias, but we shouldn’t handcuff good officers from doing their jobs and keeping folks safe. Strong oversight that’s local and transparent can help rebuild trust without tearing down the whole system.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime studying history, I’ve seen how deeply mistrust can run when law enforcement is perceived as unfair or biased, and how corrosive that is to democracy and community life. We need stronger standards, training, and accountability around use of force and implicit bias, along with independent oversight, but we also need to invest in community-based approaches—mental health responders, youth programs, and neighborhood policing that builds real relationships. From my Catholic and progressive perspective, protecting human dignity must be at the center of public safety policy, which means valuing every life equally and being transparent when things go wrong. Done right, these reforms don’t weaken good policing; they make it more effective, more trusted, and ultimately safer for everyone, including officers.

As a liberal, community-oriented guy who volunteers locally and cares about civil rights, I think policing has to start with real accountability and transparency—body cameras, independent review boards, and clear consequences when officers abuse power. We need serious, ongoing anti-bias and de-escalation training, and we should be investing more in social services and community programs so cops aren’t the default response to every problem. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be safe, so I support well-trained officers who actually know and work with the communities they serve instead of just patrolling them.

As someone who’s grown up hearing stories about police mistreating people of color, I think we need stronger rules and real consequences when officers show bias or use excessive force, because trust is impossible without accountability. At the same time, we should invest more in community-based programs, mental health services, and better training focused on de-escalation so police aren’t always using force as the first answer.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over 68 years and believes in both fairness and safety, I think police departments need stronger training in de-escalation, implicit bias, and mental health response, along with clear rules and real accountability when force is misused. We can support officers who do their jobs honorably while insisting on transparency—like body cameras and independent investigations—so that communities, especially those historically mistreated, can trust that the law is applied equally.

I think police should be trained a lot more on how to calm situations down without violence and on understanding different cultures, especially in neighborhoods like mine where people speak Spanish and come from other countries. There should be clear rules and cameras so if an officer uses force, it gets checked and they’re held accountable, but we also need enough good officers around so people feel safe walking home or going to work.

As someone who’s lived a long life, taught many children, and seen both progress and painful setbacks, I believe policing must be grounded in accountability, transparency, and respect for every person’s dignity. We should require rigorous de-escalation and anti-bias training, collect and publicly share detailed use-of-force data, and ensure independent investigations when harm occurs—while also funding mental health services and community-based programs that prevent crime before it happens. Maintaining public safety and reducing bias are not competing goals; building trust through fair, evidence-based practices makes everyone safer, including the officers.

Police have a tough job, and most of them are trying to do the right thing, but they still need solid, ongoing training to handle tense situations without jumping straight to force. We should hold officers accountable when they clearly cross the line, but not by tying their hands so much that they can’t protect law-abiding people. Better body cam use, clear rules, and community meetings where cops actually talk with locals would help cut down on bias and build trust. I want to feel safe in my own neighborhood and also know that the police are being fair and professional with everyone.

I think police should treat everyone fairly and kindly, like how teachers are supposed to treat all kids the same, no matter what they look like. They should only use force when they really have to, and they should have to explain what they did so people can trust them. I feel safer when I know grown‑ups who protect us are honest and follow rules, because that helps everyone in the neighborhood feel less scared and more like friends.

My mommy and daddy say police should be nice and fair to everybody, no matter what color their skin is, and they shouldn’t hurt people unless they really, really have to. I feel safer when grown‑ups talk and listen instead of yelling or fighting, and I want the police to help people when they’re scared, like in my cartoons when heroes protect everyone.

I think police should always try to talk first and be calm so nobody gets hurt, especially people who might be treated unfairly just because of how they look. My mom tells me some kids in our neighborhood get scared when they see police, so I think officers should come to schools and parks to know us and show they want to protect us, not hurt us.

As a Haitian-American police officer and a man of faith, I believe we honor both God and the community when we treat every person with dignity, regardless of race or background. We need rigorous training, body cameras, clear use-of-force policies, and firm accountability so that bad actors are removed, but we also must support the many officers who serve honorably and risk their lives daily. Good policing requires both strong discipline and strong relationships with the community—officers should be visible, respectful, and willing to listen, but also empowered to act decisively against real threats. If we stay committed to fairness, personal responsibility, and the rule of law, we can reduce bias and excessive force without sacrificing public safety.

As a 53-year-old white guy from Ohio who’s liberal and health-conscious, I see policing a bit like public health: prevention, transparency, and accountability matter more than just reacting with force. We need stronger de-escalation training, strict use-of-force standards, body cameras, and real consequences for misconduct, alongside independent oversight to address racial bias. At the same time, officers should be supported with better pay, mental health resources, and training so they can safely do their jobs without defaulting to violence. Investing in community programs, mental health services, and social support will reduce crime at its roots and help rebuild trust between police and the neighborhoods they serve.

As a naturalized Iranian-American and a practicing attorney, I’ve seen firsthand how biased policing and excessive force erode trust in the very system that’s supposed to protect us. We need evidence-based reforms: rigorous de-escalation and bias training, truly independent civilian oversight with real power, transparent data on stops and force, and clear, enforced limits on when force can be used. None of this is anti-police; it’s pro–rule of law. When communities—especially women, immigrants, and minorities—trust that officers are accountable, public safety improves for everyone.

Police officers have a tough job, and we need them to keep our communities safe, but that doesn’t mean they shouldn’t be held to clear standards. I believe in strong training on de-escalation and fair treatment for everyone, along with body cameras and firm consequences when officers abuse their power. At the same time, we should respect and support good officers who follow the rules, because without law and order, none of us are truly safe.

As a young, liberal Protestant who wants both my community and the people who serve it to be safe, I think policing needs stronger accountability, better de-escalation training, and real transparency about use-of-force incidents. We should invest more in mental health responders and community-based programs so cops aren’t the default answer to every problem, while also using body cams, bias training, and clear, enforced standards to cut down on discriminatory stops and excessive force.

As a liberal, Catholic, family-focused software developer, I want policing that keeps my kids and community safe while also being deeply accountable and fair. We need strong national standards for use of force, mandatory body cameras, and real transparency around complaints and outcomes, combined with implicit bias training and independent oversight so people can trust that officers are held to high ethical standards. At the same time, we should invest in alternatives like mental health responders, community-based violence prevention, and better social services so police aren’t the default for every crisis. Public safety and civil rights aren’t in conflict—we should insist on both.

As a young Navajo mom raising kids in a country where people who look like us and our relatives of color are often over-policed, I want safer communities without feeling like we have to be scared of the people who are supposed to protect us. Police should be trained deeply on de-escalation, bias, and our communities’ histories, and there need to be real consequences when they use force unnecessarily. We also need more funding for mental health services, youth programs, and community-based responders so officers aren’t the only answer to every problem. Public safety should mean everyone—especially Native and Black and Brown people—can walk around without feeling like a target.

I’m little, but my grandma tells me that police are supposed to keep us safe and treat everyone fairly, no matter what they look like. I think they should learn to listen more, talk nicely, and not hurt people unless they really have to. At church we learn that everyone is a child of God, so police should remember that and be kind and careful with all families in our neighborhood.

As a Black father raising kids in this country, I want policing that protects us without treating us like suspects by default. We need real accountability for excessive force, better training that focuses on de-escalation and bias, and officers who actually know and are invested in the communities they serve. At the same time, I don’t want safety thrown out the window—serious crimes still need a strong, professional response. But that response has to be rooted in respect, transparency, and the belief that every person’s life and dignity matter.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe policing must be grounded in the same principles I try to model in my classroom: dignity, fairness, and accountability. We should invest in rigorous bias training, de-escalation tactics, mental health partnerships, and meaningful community oversight so that officers are equipped and required to use force only as a last resort. At the same time, we need to support good officers with proper resources and clear standards so they can keep communities safe without communities—especially communities of color—feeling targeted or afraid.

As a retired teacher and a lifelong Democrat, I believe policing should prioritize de-escalation, rigorous anti-bias training, and strong accountability measures so that no one is treated differently because of their race, income, or neighborhood. We can maintain public safety by investing in mental health services, community programs, and non-police responses for crises, while ensuring that officers who misuse force are held transparently and consistently accountable.

As someone who works in our local schools and cares deeply about both safety and fairness, I believe policing needs stronger accountability and de-escalation training, especially around implicit bias, so that every person—regardless of race or background—is treated with dignity. We should invest more in community-based programs, mental health support, and social services so officers aren’t asked to handle every crisis with force. At the same time, I want officers to have the tools and support they need to respond quickly and appropriately when there is a genuine threat to public safety. Building trust between police and the communities they serve—through transparency, body cameras, and meaningful civilian oversight—is essential for everyone to feel protected.

I think police should try really hard to treat everyone fairly and not judge people because of what they look like or where they come from, because in my church we learn that everyone is equal before God. They should get more training on calming people down without hurting them, but also still be there to protect us when something dangerous happens so kids and families can feel safe in their neighborhoods.

I think police should try really hard to treat everyone fairly and kindly, no matter what they look like or where they’re from, because everyone deserves to feel safe. They should learn better ways to calm people down without hurting them, and practice listening more before using force. I’d feel safer if officers spent more time getting to know the kids and families in our neighborhoods so we can trust each other and work together to keep our communities peaceful.

As a dad raising kids and working hard to keep a roof over our heads, I want police to be both fair and effective, because my family’s safety depends on them doing their jobs right. I think departments should invest more in training on de-escalation and bias, use body cameras consistently, and be transparent and accountable when force is used. At the same time, officers need solid support, clear rules, and enough staffing so they’re not constantly stretched thin and making decisions under impossible pressure. That balance—firm accountability and strong community trust—seems like the best way to reduce unnecessary force while still keeping our neighborhoods safe.

As someone who believes in personal responsibility and respects law enforcement, I think we need strong, well-funded police who are thoroughly trained in de-escalation, cultural awareness, and clear, consistent use-of-force standards. Bias and misconduct should be taken seriously with real accountability, body cameras, and better screening and supervision, but we shouldn’t demonize all officers for the actions of a few. Community policing that builds relationships—especially in working-class and Hispanic neighborhoods like mine—can reduce tensions and help both sides trust each other more. In the end, the goal should be to protect innocent people, support good cops, and make sure everyone is treated fairly under the law.

As a dad, a chef, and a lifelong Illinoisan, I want my kids to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and the police can trust them. We need stronger de-escalation training, real accountability for excessive force, and independent oversight so that officers who abuse their power are removed while good officers are supported. Bias—whether racial, cultural, or otherwise—has to be confronted head-on with consistent training, better recruitment, and real community engagement, not just photo ops. If we invest in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based responses alongside fair, well-trained policing, we can be both safer and more just.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime working with the law and believes deeply in both justice and order, I think policing strategies have to balance firm enforcement with strong accountability. We need better training on de-escalation and bias, clear body-camera policies, and swift, fair investigations when force is used, but we must also make sure officers have the resources and public backing to confront genuine threats. Community policing—where officers know the neighborhoods and the people they serve—can reduce mistrust, improve safety, and help ensure that everyone, regardless of background, is treated with dignity under the law.

At my age, I’ve lived long enough to see that when policing is done right, it can protect communities without trampling anyone’s dignity. We need stronger training in de-escalation and bias awareness, clear, enforced rules on use of force, and real accountability when officers cross the line—no sweeping things under the rug. At the same time, officers should have the support, resources, and staffing they need so they aren’t pushed into treating every situation like a crisis. Protecting public safety and insisting on fair, respectful treatment—especially for marginalized groups—go hand in hand, not one or the other.

As someone who spends all day driving around this city and talking with people from every walk of life, I see how much damage is done when communities don’t trust the police—especially when bias and excessive force go unaddressed. We need strict accountability measures, body cameras, de-escalation and anti-bias training, and independent investigations of use-of-force incidents, alongside diverting many mental health and low-level issues to specialized responders instead of armed officers. At the same time, I want well-trained officers who are part of the community, not an occupying force—people who know the neighborhoods, walk the streets, and build relationships so that safety comes from cooperation, not fear.

As a naturalized citizen, a dad, and a manager who thinks a lot about systems and accountability, I believe policing needs clear, enforced standards that dramatically reduce bias and excessive force while still giving officers the tools they genuinely need to keep communities safe. That means rigorous de-escalation training, body cameras, independent oversight of misconduct, and data-driven reviews of stops and arrests, alongside fair pay and mental health support for officers so they can do their jobs well. As a liberal Catholic, I see the dignity of every person—both civilian and officer—as non-negotiable, and our policies should reflect that by prioritizing preservation of life and equal treatment under the law.

I respect the tough job cops have, and I want my community to be safe, but I don’t think that gives anyone a free pass to abuse their power or treat people differently because of how they look. I’d like to see better training in de-escalation and dealing with people in crisis, more body cameras with real consequences when they’re misused, and local oversight so departments answer to the communities they serve. If we back good officers, weed out the bad ones, and make the rules and accountability clear, we can cut down on bias and excessive force without tying police hands when it comes to stopping real crime.

As a teacher, a mom, and a Democrat who cares about both justice and safety in my community, I believe policing needs strong, enforceable standards to reduce bias and excessive force—things like mandatory de-escalation training, transparent data reporting, and real civilian oversight with teeth. At the same time, we should shift some responsibilities away from armed officers and toward mental health and social service professionals, while investing in community-based prevention and youth programs so officers are partners in safety, not an occupying force.

As a Black Trinidadian American woman and a liberal Jewish voter, I believe policing must confront racial bias and excessive force head-on through mandatory de-escalation training, transparent accountability, and independent oversight. We can maintain public safety more effectively by investing in mental health responders, community-based programs, and neighborhood partnerships, so police are not the default answer to every crisis.

As a healthcare professional who works closely with people in pain and vulnerability, I believe policing must prioritize de-escalation, implicit-bias training, and strict accountability for excessive force, while still ensuring officers have the support and resources needed to respond effectively to real threats. We should invest heavily in community-based programs, mental health responders, and youth services alongside evidence-based reforms to use-of-force policies, so public safety is built on trust, fairness, and respect for human dignity rather than fear.

I think most police officers are trying to do the right thing, and we need to support them with better training, clear rules, and the resources to do their jobs safely. At the same time, we should use body cameras, standardized use-of-force policies, and data-driven reviews to catch and correct bias or misconduct when it happens. Accountability and respect for citizens’ rights can go hand-in-hand with tough, consistent enforcement that keeps our communities safe.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime in a busy kitchen, I know you can’t run anything safely without clear rules, accountability, and respect for everyone on the team—and I think policing should be no different. We need better training that emphasizes de-escalation and recognizing our own biases, along with body cameras and transparent consequences when officers cross the line, so people can trust that the law is applied fairly. At the same time, I believe most officers are trying to do a tough job, and they need strong support, staffing, and community relationships so they can keep neighborhoods safe without resorting to unnecessary force.

As a mom raising kids in this community, I want police who are both fair and firm, because we depend on them to keep our neighborhoods safe. I support strong training to reduce bias and excessive force—like body cameras, de-escalation skills, and better mental health support—while still backing officers who do their jobs correctly and bravely. We should hold bad actors accountable without demonizing the whole profession, and encourage closer relationships between officers and the families they serve so there’s trust on both sides.

As a Native woman and a federal police officer, I believe we can’t talk about public safety without talking honestly about bias and how force is used, especially in communities that have been over-policed and under-protected for generations. We need better training that’s grounded in de-escalation, cultural humility, and mental health awareness, paired with strong accountability systems—body cameras, transparent investigations, and real consequences when lines are crossed. At the same time, we should invest in community-based programs and partnerships that address the root causes of crime, so officers are working with neighborhoods instead of just showing up when things have already gone wrong. That balance—firm on safety, firm on justice—is the only way people will truly trust us to wear this badge.

As a young Black girl, I’ve grown up seeing stories of people who look like me being treated unfairly by police, so I think departments need strict rules, better training, and real accountability when officers use force. At the same time, I believe public safety is important, and that comes from building trust—having officers who know the community, don’t assume the worst about people, and work with neighbors, schools, and local leaders instead of just showing up when something goes wrong.

As someone who cares deeply about my neighbors’ safety and dignity, I believe policing has to be rooted in strong community relationships, meaningful bias training, and real accountability when officers misuse force. We should invest more in de-escalation training, mental health responders, and social services so that police aren’t the only answer to every problem, while still ensuring they have the tools and support to respond quickly and fairly to serious crime.

As a conservative, family-oriented mother, I believe we absolutely need strong, well-funded police to keep our neighborhoods safe, but that doesn’t mean we ignore real problems with bias and excessive force. We should focus on better training in de-escalation, mental health, and cultural awareness, along with body cameras and clear accountability when officers abuse their power. At the same time, we must respect good officers, support them with the resources they need, and encourage community policing so that trust can grow on both sides. This balanced approach protects our families and our rights without demonizing all law enforcement.

As someone who’s grown up in a small town and been taught in church that everyone’s made in the image of God, I think police need strong, consistent training to recognize and reduce bias, plus body cameras and clear rules on use of force so things are transparent and fair. At the same time, I don’t want to feel unsafe at school or in my neighborhood, so I think we should invest in both better community policing and better support for officers—like mental health resources and de-escalation training—so they can protect people without letting fear or prejudice drive their decisions.

Como alguien que vino de México y trabaja duro todos los días, yo quiero sentir que la policía me protege, no que me mira con sospecha por mi acento o mi cara. Pienso que los policías necesitan mejor entrenamiento para controlar el uso de la fuerza, aprender más sobre las comunidades que sirven, y enfrentar el racismo y los prejuicios dentro del sistema. También es importante que haya cámaras, reglas claras y consecuencias reales cuando un oficial abusa de su poder, porque la confianza se gana con transparencia y justicia. Si la policía respeta a la comunidad y escucha a la gente trabajadora y a los inmigrantes, será más fácil colaborar con ellos para mantener la seguridad de todos.

I believe most police officers are trying to do a hard job well, and we need to support them while also insisting on fairness and accountability. Clear standards on use of force, better training in de-escalation, and body cameras can help address bias and rebuild trust without tying officers’ hands. Local communities should be involved in setting priorities and reviewing serious incidents, but we should be careful not to demonize the whole profession based on the actions of a few. Public safety and respect for everyone’s rights ought to go hand in hand.

My parents want me to grow up in a world where police see me as a child to protect, not a threat to control, so they believe training to recognize and undo bias has to be a core part of policing. They say officers should be taught to slow situations down, use force only when truly necessary, and build real relationships with the communities they serve, especially Black families like mine.

As a Democrat and someone who cares deeply about both community well-being and fairness, I think policing has to be guided by strong accountability, de-escalation training, and transparent data on stops and use of force to address bias head-on. We should invest more in mental health responders, community-based violence prevention, and better officer training so that police are not the default answer to every problem, while still having the tools and support they need to respond effectively to serious crime.

As someone who values law and order but also believes every person should be treated fairly, I think policing should focus on strong training, clear rules, and accountability without weakening officers’ ability to do their jobs. Officers need better de-escalation training and support so they can avoid unnecessary use of force, and departments should remove those who repeatedly abuse their authority. At the same time, we should respect and back the many good officers who protect our communities every day, because public safety and trust in the police have to go hand in hand.

As a young dad and small business owner, I want my kids to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and also feel safe playing in the yard. We need stronger accountability and transparency—things like body cameras, independent investigations of use-of-force, and mandatory de-escalation and anti-bias training—so officers are held to a high standard. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health responders, youth programs, and community-based violence prevention, so police aren’t the default answer to every problem and can focus on genuinely dangerous situations. That balance—firm oversight plus smarter, community-centered safety—is how we protect both civil rights and public safety.

As someone who believes in law and order and deeply respects the difficult job officers do, I still think we need consistent standards and better training to reduce bias and unnecessary use of force. Body cameras, clear procedures, and strong accountability can protect both the public and good officers. At the same time, we shouldn’t handcuff the police from doing their job—public safety has to come first, but it should be carried out fairly and with respect for everyone’s rights.

As someone who works in a highly regulated, data-driven industry, I think policing needs to be guided by the same evidence-based rigor we demand in pharmaceutical process design: standardized protocols, continuous monitoring, and transparent accountability. We should mandate robust de-escalation training, collect and openly analyze detailed use-of-force and stop data to identify and correct bias, and shift some responsibilities—like mental health crises and addiction issues—to specialized responders. Done right, these reforms don’t undermine public safety; they make it more reliable, equitable, and scientifically grounded.

As someone who spends her life trying to move people through music, I believe policing should be rooted in de-escalation, cultural competence, and a deep respect for human dignity, with clear accountability when officers abuse their power. We need stronger bias training, independent investigations into use-of-force incidents, and a shift in resources toward mental health services and community-based programs so that officers aren’t the blunt instrument for every social problem. That said, I recognize the importance of public safety, and I think the most effective way to achieve it is for police to work in genuine partnership with the communities they serve, not in opposition to them.

As a Black teen growing up in Texas, I’ve seen how bias and excessive force from police can hurt trust in entire communities like mine, so reform isn’t optional—it’s necessary. We need stronger accountability measures, better training in de-escalation and anti-racism, and more community-based approaches that treat people with dignity while still responding quickly and effectively to real threats. True public safety means everyone feels protected, not targeted.

As someone who spent my career as a park ranger, I know you can enforce rules and keep people safe without treating them like the enemy. Police departments need strong de-escalation training, real accountability for misconduct, and community-based approaches that recognize the dignity of every person, regardless of race or background. Just like in conservation, prevention is better than reaction: investing in mental health services, youth programs, and neighborhood trust reduces the need for force in the first place. Public safety and fairness are not opposites—they depend on each other.

I think we need good cops and safe streets, but that has to go hand in hand with fair treatment for everyone, no matter their race or background. Departments should put more effort into training on de-escalation and bias, use body cameras consistently, and hold officers accountable when they cross the line. At the same time, we’ve got to support the many officers who do their jobs right with enough staffing, mental health support, and clear rules so they can respond quickly and decisively when there’s real danger.

As a mom, a teacher, and a progressive Democrat, I want my kids to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and where no one is treated differently because of their race or background. We need stronger de-escalation and bias training, independent investigations when force is used, and clear accountability when officers violate standards—because rules without consequences change nothing. At the same time, investing in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based supports will prevent many situations from escalating to police involvement in the first place, which ultimately keeps both residents and officers safer.

As a young Black man from Texas who practices yoga and cares a lot about community and spirituality, I think policing has to start with seeing people’s humanity first. We need strong de-escalation training, strict accountability for biased or excessive use of force, and more investment in mental health and community-based responses so police aren’t the only tool we rely on. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be safe, so I support well-trained officers who build real relationships with residents instead of treating us like suspects by default. That balance—firm accountability plus genuine community partnership—is how we protect both public safety and civil rights.

As someone who’s grown up hearing a lot about police violence and bias, especially toward people who look like me, I think policing needs way more transparency, training, and accountability so officers are actually held responsible when they abuse their power. At the same time, keeping communities safe shouldn’t just mean more cops and more force—it should mean investing in mental health support, youth programs, and community-based approaches so officers are partners with us, not people we’re scared of.

Working as an investigator in the private sector, I see every day how critical trust and accountability are to getting people to talk and to keeping situations from escalating. I believe policing should prioritize de-escalation, rigorous bias training, and real transparency—body cameras, independent review boards, and clear consequences for misconduct—while also investing in mental health professionals and community-based responders to handle many of the crises we currently send armed officers to. When people know that force is a last resort, not a default, they’re more likely to cooperate, which ultimately makes everyone safer.

As a liberal, Jewish Texan with a disability and no safety net like health insurance, I’m deeply aware of how vulnerable people can be when systems of power aren’t held accountable. Policing strategies should prioritize de-escalation, implicit bias training, mental health responders, and strong civilian oversight so that force is truly a last resort, not a routine tool—especially in marginalized communities. At the same time, communities deserve to feel safe from violence and crime, which means investing in prevention, social services, and neighborhood-based partnerships that reduce the need for police interventions in the first place.

As someone who believes strongly in law and order and has built a life here through hard work, I think we need to support our police while also holding them to consistently high professional standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, clear use-of-force protocols, and body cameras so that both officers and citizens are protected and situations are documented. At the same time, we must reject broad-brush accusations against all officers and instead focus on identifying and removing bad actors, improving leadership, and building trust through transparency. That balance—backing the good cops, fixing what’s broken, and enforcing the law firmly and fairly—is what keeps communities safe.

As someone who spent her life caring for vulnerable people, I believe we absolutely need clear, strict standards and better training to reduce bias and prevent unnecessary use of force, while still allowing police to do the hard job of keeping us safe. I support strong accountability when officers cross the line, but I also think we should give them the tools, staffing, and community support they need so they don’t feel backed into a corner. I’d like to see more community policing, where officers really know the neighborhoods they serve, along with ongoing training in de-escalation and implicit bias that doesn’t demonize them but helps them do their job more fairly.

As someone who grew up here in North Carolina and works hard just to get by, I think we need police who are both respected and held clearly accountable. I support more training on de-escalation and bias, body cameras that actually get reviewed, and firm consequences when officers cross the line, because no one should be treated differently based on who they are. At the same time, I want officers well-staffed, better paid, and supported so they’re not overworked or scared every time they respond to a call, since that just makes bad outcomes more likely for everyone. We should aim for a system where cops and communities know each other, trust each other, and follow the rules on both sides.

I think police should try really hard to be kind and fair to everyone, no matter what they look like, so people don’t feel scared just because of who they are. They should learn to stay calm and talk things out first instead of hurting people, and only use force if there is really no other way to keep everyone safe. If police spend time getting to know families and kids in the neighborhood, it would help us trust them more and feel safer playing outside.

As someone who cares deeply about justice and community well-being, I think policing has to be rooted in transparency, de-escalation, and strong accountability when force is used or bias is shown. We need robust training on implicit bias and mental health, independent review of serious incidents, and a shift in funding toward community services and non-police crisis responders so officers aren’t asked to be everything to everyone. At the same time, building genuine relationships between officers and the neighborhoods they serve—through consistent, respectful engagement—can improve safety without relying on aggressive tactics that disproportionately harm marginalized communities.

As a retired woman who’s seen a lot of news and heartbreak over the years, I believe police need much stronger accountability, de-escalation training, and clear standards to prevent bias and excessive force, especially against communities of color. At the same time, I know communities still need to feel safe, so we should invest in mental health services, social workers, and community-based programs that can handle many situations without armed officers being the first resort.

As someone who spent her career working to protect both the environment and public health, I believe policing should be guided by evidence-based practices that reduce harm and build trust, especially in communities that have historically borne the brunt of bias and excessive force. We need strong accountability measures, rigorous de-escalation and anti-bias training, transparent data on stops and use of force, and a greater investment in social services and community-based programs so that police are not the default response to every problem. At the same time, I support well-trained officers who see themselves as partners with the community, not occupiers, and who are given the tools and oversight necessary to keep everyone safe—civilians and officers alike.

As a liberal, tech-focused professional and a dad, I want policing strategies that are both data-driven and deeply humane. We should be using technology—like body cameras, transparent data dashboards, and rigorous analytics—to identify and reduce bias and excessive force, paired with strong accountability measures and independent oversight. At the same time, we need to invest in better training around de-escalation and mental health, and shift some responsibilities to social services so officers aren’t the default for every crisis. That’s how we maintain public safety while making sure communities—especially marginalized ones—are treated fairly and with respect.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in the dignity of every human being, I think policing must be both firm and fair. We should invest in better training that emphasizes de-escalation, respect for all communities, and clear rules on use of force, while also backing officers who follow those rules and put themselves in harm’s way. Independent review of serious incidents, along with body cameras and transparent reporting, can help address bias without undermining the authority officers need to keep our streets safe.

As someone who believes strongly in personal responsibility and law and order, I think we need well-funded, well-trained police who are held to high professional standards, not weakened or vilified. Departments should invest in rigorous training on de-escalation, fair treatment, and unbiased decision-making, and then back officers who follow those procedures while swiftly removing those who don’t. Transparent reporting on use-of-force and body camera footage can build public trust, but we also need communities to respect the difficult, often dangerous job officers do. Public safety and civil rights aren’t opposing goals—we can and should insist on both.

As someone who believes in law and order and has deep respect for the tough job officers do, I still think we need solid, fair training to reduce bias and make sure force is only used when absolutely necessary. Police should wear body cameras, be held accountable when they cross the line, and work closely with the community so people feel respected, not targeted. At the same time, we must support good officers with proper pay, staffing, and resources so they can keep our neighborhoods safe without being afraid to do their jobs.

I think police should try really hard to be fair to everyone and not just think someone is bad because of how they look or where they’re from. They should have to practice talking things out calmly and only use force if they really, really have to, like a last resort. Grown-ups should also check what the police are doing and teach them better ways to help people so everyone can feel safe, like my family and my friends when we’re walking to synagogue or playing outside.

As someone who backs the blue but also believes every life is precious in God’s eyes, I think we need both strong law enforcement and strong accountability. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, mental health, and community relations, while making sure officers who abuse their power face real consequences. At the same time, we must support good officers with the tools, staffing, and public respect they need to confront violent crime and keep our neighborhoods safe. Balancing firm, fair policing with transparency and body cameras can help reduce bias and excessive force without tying officers’ hands.

As someone who believes in law and order but also knows what it feels like to be looked at differently as a Black woman, I think police need strong, consistent training that focuses on de-escalation, treating everyone with dignity, and rooting out any bias, whether conscious or not. At the same time, officers deserve clear rules, community support, and the tools they need to stay safe, because we rely on them when things go wrong. I’d like to see more officers truly embedded in the neighborhoods they serve, building relationships through churches, schools, and local events so that trust goes both ways and deadly force becomes a last resort.

As someone who’s worn a uniform and believes strongly in individual liberty, I think policing has to be rooted in strict accountability and transparency, not blind loyalty to the badge. We should use body cameras, independent civilian review boards, and rigorous de-escalation training to reduce bias and excessive force, while still making sure officers have the tools and backing to confront real threats. Policies should be laser-focused on protecting constitutional rights, not padding arrest stats, and bad actors in any department should be removed quickly so the public can trust the officers who are doing it right.

As a mom and a nursing assistant, I see every day how treating people with dignity can calm tense situations, and I think policing should work the same way. We need better training to reduce bias and de-escalate situations, along with body cameras and real accountability when officers abuse their power, but I also want officers to have the resources they need to respond quickly when our families are in danger. I believe in personal freedom and privacy, so any policing strategy should focus on targeted, fair enforcement rather than blanket surveillance or harassing certain communities.

I believe most police officers are good people trying to keep our communities safe, and they deserve respect and support, but they also need strong training and clear standards so everyone is treated fairly. We should focus on better training in de-escalation, mental health situations, and community relations, along with body cameras and accountability when officers cross the line. That way, we can address bias and excessive force without weakening law enforcement or putting law-abiding citizens at greater risk.

As someone who believes in fairness, responsibility, and taking care of our neighbors, I think policing needs strong accountability measures—like body cameras, transparent investigations, and independent oversight—to reduce bias and excessive force without sacrificing safety. Officers should be well-trained in de-escalation, mental health response, and implicit bias, and our communities should invest more in social services, education, and violence prevention so police aren’t the first and only answer to every problem.
